nodes.text: IoT-based smart home systems can simultaneously enhance household energy efficiency and security, enabling sustainable and safer living environments
Core IoT smart home architecture comprises sensors, actuators, controllers, and communication protocols (ZigBee, Z-Wave, Wi-Fi, BLE, Thread) that enable data collection, automation, and control
IoT-enabled energy management using real-time monitoring, automation, and AI/ML can reduce household energy consumption by up to approximately 20-30% depending on application
Integrated IoT security measures including end-to-end encryption, blockchain-based authentication, and ML-based intrusion detection significantly reduce compromise rates and response times
Major barriers to realizing IoT benefits are device interoperability gaps, high initial costs, scalability and network limitations, and fragmented security standards
Sensors measure temperature, humidity, motion, light, gas and energy use; controllers (e.g., Raspberry Pi, Arduino) and actuators execute commands enabling predictive maintenance and edge processing
Communication protocols trade off range, power, and bandwidth: ZigBee/Z-Wave for low-power sensor networks, Wi-Fi for high-bandwidth tasks like video, Thread for IPv6 scalability
Evidence from studies and case examples: smart thermostats reduce heating costs by 10-12% and cooling costs by 15%; a 1,000-home California deployment saved 1.2 GWh in one year
AI/ML and demand response enable 20-25% additional optimization per industry reports; integration with renewable sources and VPPs can improve utilization by 30-40%
Empirical security evidence: properly encrypted IoT devices show substantially fewer compromises (e.g., reports citing 70% fewer compromises); IDS reduces response times from hours to milliseconds
Blockchain and smart contracts can authenticate devices and automate access control, studies suggest up to 50% reduction in certain IoT cyber risks
Interoperability is limited by proprietary protocols and fragmentation; around 60% of smart devices face compatibility issues in multi-vendor networks
High upfront deployment costs (estimated $1,500 to $2,000 per household) and protocol scalability issues (ZigBee/Z-Wave limits) hinder adoption and large-scale performance
Future enabling technologies such as 5G/6G, edge computing, AI, quantum cryptography, and standardized protocols (Thread, Matter) are expected to address latency, scalability, and security gaps

Recommendation: combine AI-driven optimization, end-to-end encryption, blockchain, regulatory standardization, and public-private partnerships to accelerate secure, interoperable, and energy-efficient IoT home adoption
